description: Borrowed from Latin ēlēctus, past participle of ēligō (“to pick out, choose, elect”), from ē- (“out”) + legō (“to pick out, pick, gather, collect, etc.”); see legend.
Cognate to eclectic, which is via Ancient Greek rather than Latin, hence prefix ἐκ (ek), rather than e- (from ex).

entries.meaning: (postpositive) Who has been elected in a specified post, but has not yet entered office.
Chosen; taken by preference from among two or more.
(theology) In Calvinist theology, one foreordained to Heaven. In other Christian theologies, someone chosen by God for salvation.

verbs.description: elect (third-person singular simple present elects, present participle electing, simple past and past participle elected)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To choose or make a decision (to do something)
(transitive) To choose (a candidate) in an election
